[[File:Response surface metodology.jpg|thumb|Designed experiments with full factorial design (left), response surface with second-degree polynomial (right)]]
In statistics, '''response surface methodology (RSM)''' explores the relationships between several [[explanatory variable]]s and one or more [[response variable]]s. The method was introduced by [[George E. P. Box]] and K. B. Wilson in 1951. The main idea of RSM is to use a sequence of [[design of experiments|designed experiments]] to obtain an optimal response. Box and Wilson suggest using a [[Degree of a polynomial|second-degree]] [[polynomial]] model to do this. They acknowledge that this model is only an approximation, but they use it because such a model is easy to estimate and apply, even when little is known about the process.
Statistical approaches such as RSM can be employed to maximize the production of a special substance by optimization of operational factors. In contrast to conventional methods, the interaction among process variables can be determined by statistical techniques.<ref name="Organosolv">{{cite journal|last1=Asadi|first1=Nooshin|last2=Zilouei|first2=Hamid|title=Optimization of organosolv pretreatment of rice straw for enhanced biohydrogen production using Enterobacter aerogenes|journal=Bioresource Technology|date=March 2017|volume=227|pages=335–344|doi=10.1016/j.biortech.2016.12.073|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/311881656_Optimization_of_organosolv_pretreatment_of_rice_straw_for_enhanced_biohydrogen_production_using_Enterobacter_aerogenes}}</ref><ref>Ahmed Maged, Salah Haridy, Mohammad Shamsuzzaman, Imad Alsyouf, and Roubi Zaied. (2018).[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/326072519_Statistical_Monitoring_and_Optimization_of_Electrochemical_Machining_using_Shewhart_Charts_and_Response_Surface_Methodology Statistical Monitoring and Optimization of Electrochemical Machining using Shewhart Charts and Response Surface Methodology.] 3(2), 68-77. https://doi.org/10.26776/ijemm.03.02.2018.01</ref> The work by Box and co-workers was summarized in the book <ref>{{Cite book|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/0470072768|title=Response Surfaces, Mixtures, and Ridge Analyses|last=Box|first=George E. P.|last2=Draper|first2=Norman R.|date=2007-03-09|publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Inc.|isbn=9780470072769|location=Hoboken, NJ, USA}}</ref>. Other important textbooks in RSM with a more recent set of topics other than those originally studied by Box and co-workers in the 50's and 60's are <ref>{{Cite book|title=Response Surfaces: Design and Analyses|last=Khuri, A.I., and Cornell, J.A|first=|publisher=Marcel Dekker|year=1996|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/783405607|title=Process optimization : a statistical approach|last=del Castillo|first=Enrique|date=2007|publisher=Springer|year=|isbn=9780387714349|location=|pages=|oclc=783405607}}</ref>.
==Basic approach of response surface methodology== An easy way to estimate a first-degree polynomial model is to use a [[factorial experiment]] or a [[fractional factorial design]]. This is sufficient to determine which explanatory variables affect the response variable(s) of interest. Once it is suspected that only significant explanatory variables are left, then a more complicated design, such as a [[central composite design]] can be implemented to estimate a second-degree polynomial model, which is still only an approximation at best. However, the second-degree model can be used to optimize (maximize, minimize, or attain a specific target for).
==Important RSM properties and features==
''ORTHOGONALITY:'' The property that allows individual effects of the k-factors to be estimated independently without (or with minimal) confounding. Also orthogonality provides minimum variance estimates of the model coefficient so that they are uncorrelated.
''ROTATABILITY'': The property of rotating points of the design about the center of the factor space. The moments of the distribution of the design points are constant.
''UNIFORMITY:'' A third property of CCD designs used to control the number of center points is uniform precision (or Uniformity).
==Special geometries==
===Cube=== Cubic designs are discussed by Kiefer, by Atkinson, Donev, and Tobias and by Hardin and Sloane.
===Sphere=== [[Spherical design]]s are discussed by Kiefer and by Hardin and Sloane.
===Simplex geometry and mixture experiments=== Mixture experiments are discussed in many books on the [[design of experiments]], and in the response-surface methodology textbooks of Box and Draper and of Atkinson, Donev and Tobias. An extensive discussion and survey appears in the advanced textbook by John Cornell.
==Extensions==
<!-- ===Constraints=== -->
===Multiple objective functions=== {{see also|Multiobjective optimization|Pareto efficiency}} Some extensions of response surface methodology deal with the multiple response problem. Multiple response variables create difficulty because what is optimal for one response may not be optimal for other responses. Other extensions are used to reduce variability in a single response while targeting a specific value, or attaining a near maximum or minimum while preventing variability in that response from getting too large.
==Practical concerns== Response surface methodology uses statistical models, and therefore practitioners need to be aware that even the best statistical model is an approximation to reality. In practice, both the models and the parameter values are unknown, and subject to uncertainty on top of ignorance. Of course, an estimated optimum point need not be optimum in reality, because of the errors of the estimates and of the inadequacies of the model.
Nonetheless, response surface methodology has an effective track-record of helping researchers improve products and services: For example, Box's original response-surface modeling enabled chemical engineers to improve a process that had been stuck at a saddle-point for years. The engineers had not been able to afford to fit a cubic three-level design to estimate a quadratic model, and their [[Bias (statistics)|biased]] linear-models estimated the gradient to be zero. Box's design reduced the costs of experimentation so that a quadratic model could be fit, which led to a (long-sought) ascent direction.<ref>Box, G. E. P. and Wilson, K.B. (1951) On the Experimental Attainment of Optimum Conditions (with discussion). ''[[Journal of the Royal Statistical Society]]'' Series B'''13'''(1):1–45.</ref><ref>''Improving Almost Anything: Ideas and Essays'', Revised Edition (Wiley Series in Probability and Statistics) George E. P. Box</ref>
==See also== * [[Plackett–Burman design]] * [[Box–Behnken design]] * [[Central composite design]] * [[IOSO]] method based on response-surface methodology * [[Optimal design]]s * [[Polynomial regression]] * [[Polynomial and rational function modeling]] * [[Surrogate model]] * [[Probabilistic design]] * [[Gradient-Enhanced Kriging (GEK)]]

'''STDs in the porn industry''' deals with the [[occupational safety and health]] issue in the [[sex industry]] of transmission of [[sexually transmitted infections]] (STIs/STDs), especially [[HIV/AIDS]], which became a major cause of concern since the 1980s, especially for [[pornographic film actor]]s. {{As of|2009}}, there had been twenty-two reported [[HIV]] cases in the U.S. pornography industry; roughly half were among men who work in gay films, and the other half were men and women working in heterosexual productions.{{cite news |author= |date=24 June 2009 |title=L.A. pushes for condoms in porn legislation, but state lawmakers balk |url=http://capitolweekly.net/l-a-pushes-for-condoms-in-porn-legislation-but-state-lawmakers-balk/ |newspaper=Capitol Weekly |location=Sacramento, California |accessdate=11 March 2014}} ==Types of diseases== Because pornographic film making involves [[unsimulated sex]], usually without [[condom]]s ([[Bareback (sex)|barebacking]]), pornographic actors are particularly vulnerable to [[sexually transmitted disease]]s including [[Chlamydia infection|chlamydia]], [[gonorrhea]], [[syphilis]], and [[HIV/AIDS]].{{cite journal|last1=Rodriguez-Hart|first1=C|last2=Chitale|first2=RA|last3=Rigg|first3=R|last4=Goldstein|first4=BY|last5=Kerndt|first5=PR|last6=Tavrow|first6=P|title=Sexually transmitted infection testing of adult film performers: is disease being missed?|journal=Sexually Transmitted Diseases|date=December 2012|volume=39|issue=12|pages=989–94|doi=10.1097/OLQ.0b013e3182716e6e|pmid=23191956}}{{cite journal|last1=Grudzen|first1=CR|last2=Meeker|first2=D|last3=Torres|first3=J|last4=Du|first4=Q|last5=Andersen|first5=RM|last6=Gelberg|first6=L|title=HIV and STI risk behaviors, knowledge, and testing among female adult film performers as compared to other California women|journal=AIDS and Behavior|date=February 2013|volume=17|issue=2|pages=517–22|doi=10.1007/s10461-011-0090-0|pmid=22101890}}{{cite journal|last1=Goldstein|first1=BY|last2=Steinberg|first2=JK|last3=Aynalem|first3=G|last4=Kerndt|first4=PR|title=High Chlamydia and gonorrhea incidence and reinfection among performers in the adult film industry|journal=Sexually Transmitted Diseases|date=July 2011|volume=38|issue=7|pages=644–8|doi=10.1097/OLQ.0b013e318214e408|pmid=21844714}} ==HIV cases== ===1980s and 1990s=== [[File:BrookeAshley lg.jpg|thumb|Brooke Ashley became [[HIV positive]] in 1998 but returned to pornography in 2005 in a film with her boyfriend Eddie Wood, who was also HIV positive.[http://business.avn.com/articles/22639.html "Powers Shoots HIV-Positive, Hetero Scene"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100505083252/http://business.avn.com/articles/22639.html |date=2010-05-05 }}, by Mark Kernes, ''[[Adult Video News]]'', 2005-08-11. [http://www.avn.com/movies/62281.html "AVN Reviews: Dirty Debutantes 2005 327 & 328"], Marc Star, ''[[Adult Video News]]''. Both retrieved 2007-07-17]] According to former pornographic actress [[Shelley Lubben]], a 1980s outbreak of HIV led to the death of 27 porn stars between 1985 and 1992, including [[Wade Nichols]] (who died in 1985), [[John Holmes (actor)|John Holmes]] (1988), [[Marc Stevens (actor)|Marc Stevens]] (1989), and [[Al Parker]] (1992).{{cite web |last=Lubben |first=Shelley |date=September 3, 2013 |title=STD and HIV Outbreaks in the Porn Industry Since the 1980's |url=http://pornharmsresearch.com/2013/09/std-and-hiv-outbreaks-in-the-porn-industry-since-the-1980s/ |type=compilation |website=pornharmsresearch.com |publisher=Morality in Media |accessdate=10 September 2014}} When Nichols died in 1985, his fellow porn star [[Ron Jeremy]] denied that Nichols' death was AIDS-related.{{cite book |last=Jennings |first=David |year=2000 |chapter=Chapter 20: AIDS and Other Four-Letter Words |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=3VCVm7sc5JsC&pg=PA403 |title=Skinflicks: The Inside Story of the X-Rated Video Industry |url= |location= |publisher=David Jennings |page= |isbn=978-1-58721-184-3 |accessdate=10 September 2014}}{{rp|406}} In February 1986, Holmes was diagnosed as HIV-positive. Six months previously, he had tested negative. During the summer of 1986, Holmes, knowing his HIV status, agreed to perform in two pornographic films to be filmed in Italy, without informing the producers of his HIV status. Performers in one film, ''The Rise and Fall of the Roman Empress'', were [[Ilona Staller|Ilona "Cicciolina" Staller]], who later became a member of the Italian parliament, [[Tracey Adams]], [[Christoph Clark]], and [[Amber Lynn]].{{cite book |author=Various |year=2008 |editor-last=Patrick |editor-first=John |title=Huge |publisher=STARbooks |page=13 |isbn=978-1-934187-29-6}} Performers in the other film, ''The Devil In Mr. Holmes'', were Adams, Lynn, [[Karin Schubert]], and [[Marina Hedman]].{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} Subsequently, it was revealed that Holmes had consciously chosen not to reveal his HIV status to his producers or co-stars before engaging in unprotected sex for the filming.{{cite news |last=Holden |first=Stephen |date=12 January 2001 |title= WADD: The Life and Times of John C. Holmes |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?_r=1&res=940CE0DF1F3AF931A25752C0A9679C8B63 |type=movie review |newspaper=New York Times}}{{cite book |last=Hawes |first=William |year=2009 |title=Caligula and the fight for artistic freedom: the making, marketing and impact of the Bob Guccione film |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oflL1anesoYC |publisher=[[McFarland & Company|McFarland]] |page=203 |isbn=978-0-7864-3986-7}}{{cite news |last=Viladevall |first=Ferrán |date=16 May 2014|title=La mala vida del rey del porno |url=http://www.elmundo.es/magazine/2004/242/1084286415.html |language=Spanish |newspaper=[[El Mundo (Spain)]] |location= |accessdate=4 September 2011}} As his health failed, Holmes disingenuously attributed his condition to colon cancer and first confided that he had [[AIDS]] in January 1987.{{cite book |last=Basten |first=Fred |author2=Laurie Holmes |author3=John C. Holmes |title=Porn King: The John Holmes Story |year=1998 |publisher=John Holmes Inc. |isbn=978-1-880047-69-9}} He died from AIDS-related complications on March 13, 1988, aged 43.{{cite web |last=Scheeres |first=Julia |title=The Wonderland Murders |publisher=Turner Entertainment Networks |accessdate=20 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |url=http://www.crimelibrary.com/notorious_murders/celebrity/john_holmes/11.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071024195434/http://www.crimelibrary.com/notorious_murders/celebrity/john_holmes/11.html |archivedate=24 October 2007 |df= }} Stevens died of [[AIDS]]{{rp|405}} in 1989, aged 46.{{cite book |last=Edmonson |first=Roger |year=2000 |title=Clone: The Life and Legacy of Al Parker, Gay Superstar |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xTHijC4DkGEC |publisher=Alyson Books |location= |page=205 |isbn=978-1555835293 }} Parker died in 1992 from complications of AIDS, aged 40. [[Marc Wallice]], a known IV drug user,[http://www.excaliburfilms.com/pornlist/malepgs/Marc_Wallice.htm Excalibur's Porn Star Mall. Biography - Marc Wallice Porn Star] tested HIV positive in 1998. On April 30, 1998, he was diagnosed by [[Adult Industry Medical Health Care Foundation|Adult Industry Medical]] (AIM) as HIV positive.{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/AIDS/story?id=4130615&page=1 |title=Porn Industry Still Struggles With Condom Issue |work=ABC News |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]] |accessdate=2012-02-08}} It was alleged that he had hidden his HIV positive status for two years, with rumors that he accomplished this by using fake blood work through several HIV testing cycles to continue working.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} This speculation has been disputed and investigated using Wallice's tests,{{cite web |last=Staff |title=Marc Wallice Closer to Vindication? |url=http://business.avn.com/articles/video/Marc-Wallice-Closer-to-Vindication-36253.html |publisher=Adult Video News |accessdate=2 March 2014}}{{cite web|last=Staff|title=Marc Wallice Speaks Out on his Role in the HIV Controversy: "Brooke Ashley Is Off Her Fucking Rocker!"|url=http://business.avn.com/articles/video/Marc-Wallice-Speaks-Out-on-his-Role-in-the-HIV-Controversy-8220-Brooke-Ashley-Is-Off-Her-Fucking-Rocker-8221-36300.html|publisher=Adult Video News|accessdate=2 March 2014}} but it has not been doubted that during this period Wallice infected seven women on the set: Brooke Ashley,{{cite news |title=Powers Shoots HIV-Positive, Hetero Scene |first=Mark |last=Kernes |url=http://business.avn.com/articles/22639.html |newspaper=[[Adult Video News]] |publisher=Adult Video News, Inc. |location=Philadelphia, PA |issn=0883-7090 |oclc=12197226 |date=2005-08-11 |accessdate=2012-02-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100505083252/http://business.avn.com/articles/22639.html |archivedate=2010-05-05 |df= }} [[Tricia Devereaux]],{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/AIDS/hiv-actors-positive-test-unsettles-hub-us-porn/story?id=11892877&page=3 |title=Actor's Positive HIV Test Disrupts Filming as Clinic Traces On-Screen Sex Partners |first=Jane E. |last=Allen |year=2010 |work=ABC News |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]] |accessdate=2012-02-08}} Caroline, Nena Cherry, Jordan McKnight, Barbara Doll, and Kimberly Jade. ===2000s=== After four years of no reported HIV-issues within the industry, in April 2004, AIM diagnosed [[Darren James]] as being HIV-positive. It was concluded that James had been infected while engaging in unprotected [[anal sex]] with Brazilian actress Bianca Biaggi during a scene for the video ''Split That Booty 2'' in [[Rio de Janeiro]].[http://business.avn.com/articles/15953.html AVN - Test Results Pending for Two Performers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618141354/http://business.avn.com/articles/15953.html |date=2009-06-18 }}{{cite web |url = http://www.adultfyi.com/read.php?ID=22883 |title = Lara Roxx Timeline Begs Questions: Darren James got it from Lara Roxx, not the other way around? |author = Gene Ross |publisher = Adult FYI |date = 2007-05-27 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080313070354/http://www.adultfyi.com/read.php?ID=22883 |archivedate = 2008-03-13 |df = }}{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-041604adult-g,1,4216028.graphic |title=Pyramid of potential infection |publisher=Los Angeles Times |date=2004-04-16 |accessdate=2008-03-20 |quote=Time line of potential first and second generation infections }} AIM initiated an urgent search for other potentially infected performers.{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?&res=9C05EEDF123CF933A25756C0A9629C8B63 |title=Voice of Health in a Pornographic World |accessdate=2007-02-26 |author=Nick Madigan |date=2004-05-10 |publisher=The New York Times |quote=
Sharon Mitchell — ''Well-behaved women rarely make history'' }} It was discovered that three actresses who had worked with James shortly after his return to the [[United States]] had also become infected. These were Canadians [[Lara Roxx]] and Miss Arroyo, and Czech-born [[Jessica Dee]].{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9506E4DD143DF933A05757C0A9629C8B63 |title =New H.I.V. Infection Found in Sex-Film Industry |accessdate=2008-03-20 |author=Nick Madigan |date=2004-04-30 |publisher=The New York Times }}AVN, May 5th, 2004: [http://business.avn.com/articles/15987.html Another First-Gen Woman Diagnosed as HIV-Positive] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090821144824/http://business.avn.com/articles/15987.html |date=2009-08-21 }}AVN, April 26th, 2004: [http://business.avn.com/articles/15867.html Viral Load Results Indicate James was 'Patient Zero'] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120707155910/http://business.avn.com/articles/15867.html |date=2012-07-07 }} The heterosexual segment of the porn industry voluntarily shut down for 30 days (a 60-day moratorium was originally announced but it was lifted early) while it tried to deal with the situation.[http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/7652.php AIDS in pornography industry of California contained says adult industry body] Darren James, Jessica Dee, and Lara Roxx were barred from further production of sexually explicit content. About 60 actors who had had contact with James or Roxx were barred from working until HIV tests were completed and they were declared HIV negative. A further estimated 130 actors who had had contact with James were tested and received an HIV-negative result. A total of five actors were diagnosed with the virus by the end of the moratorium: one male and four females, including one transgender woman named Jennifer. In June 2009, AIM reported that a female adult entertainer had tested positive, though it was believed that transmission occurred in her private life. LA County Public Health claimed that there had been 16 "unreported" HIV cases in the adult film industry. The AIM Healthcare Foundation claimed those cases did not involve actors in production companies that followed their testing protocols and included members of the general public who used AIM Healthcare testing services or individuals attempting to work in the porn industry who never were able to obtain employment in adult films because of their failure to provide proof negative status for HIV or other STD.[http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-porn-hiv12-2009jun12,0,3569962.story More porn HIV cases disclosed] ===2010s=== On October 12, 2010, AIM reported that an actor or actress had been infected with HIV. The name and gender of the person was not released to the public.{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/10/porn-actor-has-tested-positive-for-hiv-industry-clinic-officials-confirm.html|title=Porn Actor has Tested Positive for HIV; Industry Clinic Officials Confirm a Quarantine is in Effect|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=October 12, 2010|accessdate=October 13, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101013025742/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com//lanow//2010//10//porn-actor-has-tested-positive-for-hiv-industry-clinic-officials-confirm.html| archivedate= 13 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} [[Vivid Entertainment]] and [[Wicked Pictures]] were the first companies to announce a production shutdown. Although [[Wicked Pictures]] allow some performers to wear condoms, the company shut down to wait for the [[quarantine]] list.{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/10/wicked-pictures-suspends-production-as-precaution-following-new-hiv-case-in-porn-performer-.html|title=Wicked Pictures and Vivid Entertainment Suspend Production as a Precaution Amid New HIV Case in Porn Performer|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=October 12, 2010|accessdate=October 13, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101016193546/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/10/wicked-pictures-suspends-production-as-precaution-following-new-hiv-case-in-porn-performer-.html| archivedate= 16 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} Several other porn studios shut down as a preventative measure.{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20101014/ap_en_ot/us_porn_industry_hiv|title=Positive HIV Test Halts Porn Shoots at Companies |publisher=Yahoo! News|date=October 13, 2010|accessdate=October 15, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101015052803/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20101014/ap_en_ot/us_porn_industry_hiv| archivedate= 15 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} At the time, no other performers tested HIV positive.{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/10/hiv-tests-negative-for-porn-actors-who-performed-with-patient-zero-.html|title=HIV Tests Negative for Porn Actors Who Performed with 'Patient Zero'|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=October 22, 2010|accessdate=October 23, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101024210518/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/10/hiv-tests-negative-for-porn-actors-who-performed-with-patient-zero-.html| archivedate= 24 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} In December, the HIV positive performer was identified as Derrick Burts. Burts had worked in both heterosexual and gay pornography.{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/health/la-me-porn-hiv-20101208,0,5306958.story | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Molly | last=Hennessy-Fiske | date=December 8, 2010 | title=HIV-positive porn performer speaks out}} Despite contracting [[gonorrhea]], [[chlamydia infection|chlamydia]] and [[syphilis]], Burts continued taking part in unprotected sex in films before quitting once he was diagnosed as being HIV positive. He was informed by the Adult Industry Medical Health Care Foundation that he had contracted the disease, which according to Burts, he received on a set outside the AIM system, while having oral sex scene with another "[[HIV positive]] male actor".{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/derrick-burts-hiv-in-pornography-the-naked-truth-2167532.html | location=London | work=The Independent | title=Derrick Burts: HIV in pornography: the naked truth | date=December 23, 2010}} In August 2011, the industry was temporarily shut down because of news of a performer was testing positive for the virus. [[Diane Duke]], executive director of the [[Free Speech Coalition]], confirmed the situation.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} Production later resumed production when a performer was retested and it came back negative.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} In June 2013, a gay male performer tested positive for HIV in a routine FSC-conducted blood test.{{cite web|title=FSC Pass|url=http://www.fscpass.com|accessdate=|date=2013}} The anonymous performer had previously worked exclusively on condom-only movies.{{cite web |url=http://www.sex.com/news/blog/adult-perfomer-tests-positive-hiv/ |title=Adult Performer Tests Positive for HIV » The Sex.com Blog |publisher=Sex.com |accessdate=2013-08-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130827212449/http://www.sex.com/news/blog/adult-perfomer-tests-positive-hiv/ |archive-date=2013-08-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }} FSC determined that the infection did not take place on-set.{{cite web |title=ViralGenealogyConclusive:PositivePerformerfromDecemberMoratoriumContractedVirusinPersonalLife |url=http://blog.aphss.org/?p=499|accessdate=20 December 2013|work=PASS Blog|date=20 December 2013}} In August 2013, an adult female performer, Cameron Bay, tested HIV positive.{{cite news|title=Porn actress' positive HIV test roils adult entertainment world|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-porn-actress-positive-hiv-test-roils-adult-entertainment-world-20130824,0,75668.story|accessdate=August 26, 2013|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=August 24, 2013|author=Abby Sewell}}{{cite news|title=Porn star Cameron Bay tests positive for HIV|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/confirmed-porn-star-cameron-bay-tests-positive-hiv-article-1.1434736|accessdate=August 26, 2013|newspaper=New York Daily News|date=August 23, 2013|author=Joe Kemp}}{{cite news|title=Porn Star Cameron Bay Opens Up About HIV Scare|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/porn-stars-center-hiv-scare-speak/story?id=20050118|accessdate=August 26, 2013|newspaper=Nightline ABC News|date=August 23, 2013|author=Sydney Lupkin}}{{cite news|title=US porn actor's HIV test prompts calls for moratorium on production|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2013/aug/25/us-porn-industry-actor-hiv|accessdate=August 26, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=August 25, 2013|author=Rory Carroll|location=Los Angeles}} In response, FSC organized an industry wide moratorium from August 21 to August 27. On September 4, Rod Daily, Cameron Bay's ex-boyfriend,http://therealpornwikileaks.com/cameron-bay-talked-michael-whiteacre-last-night/ announced he had also tested HIV positive.{{cite news|title=Rod Daily, Gay Porn Star, Says He is HIV Positive|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/04/rod-daily-gay-porn-star-hiv_n_3866682.html|accessdate= 4 September 2013|work=Huffington Post|date=4 September 2013}} Two days later, a third anonymous female performer tested positive {{cite news|title=Yet Another HIV-Positive Porn Performer Leads To Third Shutdown|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/12/06/fourth-hiv-porn_n_4401064.html|accessdate= 6 December 2013|work=Huffington Post|date=6 December 2013}} prompting FSC to organize a second moratorium from September 6 to September 20.{{cite web|title=FSC Announces Moratorium To Life On Friday, September 20|url=http://www.freespeechcoalition.com/component/content/article/232-fsc-announces-moratorium-to-lift-on-friday-september-20.html|work=FSC|date=September 2013|access-date=2014-06-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140612011243/http://www.freespeechcoalition.com/component/content/article/232-fsc-announces-moratorium-to-lift-on-friday-september-20.html|archive-date=2014-06-12|dead-url=yes|df=}} All three infections were found to have taken place off-set. Rumors surfaced of a fourth HIV positive test during September but they were never substantiated.{{cite web|title=Moratorium Update|url=https://www.freespeechcoalition.com/component/content/article/230-moratorium-update-september-9-2013.html|accessdate=9 September 2013|work=Free Speech Coalition|date=9 September 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131205073222/http://www.freespeechcoalition.com/component/content/article/230-moratorium-update-september-9-2013.html|archive-date=2013-12-05|dead-url=yes|df=}} In December 2013, a male porn actor tested HIV positive, leading FSC to halt production for one week. This infection was also determined to have taken place off-set. ==Testing and clinics== The revelations led to the creation of the [[Adult Industry Medical Health Care Foundation]] (AIM Healthcare or AIM) in 1998, which helped set up a monitoring system in the pornographic film industry in the United States, and pornographic film actors were required to be tested for HIV every 30 days.{{cite book|last=Basten|first=Fred |author2=Laurie Holmes |author3=John C. Holmes|title=Porn King: The John Holmes Story|year=1998|publisher=John Holmes Inc|isbn=978-1-880047-69-9}} The AIM system required all sexual contact to be logged, with positive test results leading to all sexual contacts for the last three to six months being contacted and re-tested. The use of condoms became standard in films featuring homosexual [[anal sex]].{{why?|date=January 2018}} Due to accurate and mandatory medical tests, HIV and [[AIDS]] cases became rare in the pornographic film industry.{{source needed|date=January 2018}} However, testing is voluntary (though refusal to be tested can result in the actor not being cast in a sex role) and there is no testing or monitoring of the pornographic film industry in other countries. There have been indications that actors have voluntarily left the industry, at least the industry in the United States, rather than be tested by AIM and have their AIDS and HIV status disclosed. AIM closed all its operations in May 2011, forcing the industry to look for other mechanisms for supporting and enforcing regular testing.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/informer/2011/05/porn_clinic_closed_aim_testing.php|title=Porn Clinic AIM Closes For Good: Valley-Based Industry Scrambles to Find New STD Testing System|last=Dennis Romero|date=May 3, 2011|work=[[LA Weekly]]|accessdate=May 3, 2011}} The gap was filled by the [[Free Speech Coalition]], which set up the APHSS system, now known as [[Performer Availability Screening Services]] (PASS).{{cite web|title=FSC Pass |url=http://www.fscpass.com|accessdate= |date=2013}} ==Legislation== ===Regulations to limit the spread of HIV=== Due to this limited outbreak, the California State government considered regulating the industry. Some proposed to mandate the wearing of [[condom]]s during sexually explicit scenes. Industry insiders say this would ruin sales of their wares since the unprotected content is one of the selling points of some of their films. They say the wearing of condoms ruins the sexual fantasies of many viewers. Insiders say that such regulation would force the industry underground, out of California or overseas where it would be more prone to health risks for performers. The non-profit [[Adult Industry Medical Health Care Foundation]] (AIM Healthcare) worked with the government, to develop policies that both the industry and the government would find acceptable.{{cite journal | pmc = 1892037 | pmid=17579507 | doi=10.1371/journal.pmed.0040126 | volume=4 | issue=6 | title=The adult film industry: time to regulate? | year=2007 | journal=PLoS Med. | pages=e126 | last1 = Grudzen | first1 = CR | last2 = Kerndt | first2 = PR}} === 2012 ballot measure in Los Angeles === In the 2012 election voters in Los Angeles were presented with [[Measure B]] ("Safer Sex In the Adult Film Industry Act") with the following text:{{cite web|url=http://www.smartvoter.org/2012/11/06/ca/la/meas/B/|title=Measure B: Safer Sex In the Adult Film Industry Act - Los Angeles County, CA|accessdate=2012-11-07}} {{quote|Shall an ordinance be adopted requiring producers of adult films to obtain a County public health permit, to require adult film performers to use condoms while engaged in sex acts, to provide proof of blood borne pathogen training course, to post permit and notices to performers, and making violations of the ordinance subject to civil fines and criminal charges?}} Proponents of the measure claimed pornography performers were significantly more likely to acquire HIV than the general population and that they are generally not given health insurance by their employers and so the tax payer would foot the bill for HIV treatment. Opponents claimed it to be a waste of tax dollars because of existing stringent HIV testing protocols and because nobody has contracted HIV on set in the past eight years in the United States.{{When|date=September 2016}} The measure passed with 57% voting for and 43% voting against.{{cite news|last=Shergold|first=Adam|title=California votes to mandate condoms in porn industry|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2229232/Measure-B-California-votes-mandate-condoms-LA-porn-industry-amid-fears-industry-leave-state.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490|accessdate=8 November 2012|newspaper=Daily Mail (London)|date=8 November 2012}}{{cite news|title=Porn industry trade group vows to fight condom requirement|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2012/11/porn-industry-trade-group-plans-to-fight-condom-decision.html|accessdate=8 November 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=7 November 2012}} The [[AIDS Healthcare Foundation]] tried several times to have California's Department of Industrial Relations, Division of Occupational Safety and Health's Appeals Board force companies in the pornography industry to treat actors and actresses as employees subject to [[occupational safety and health]] regulation; in a 2014 case brought against [[Treasure Island Media]] an administrative judge found that the company did have to comply with regulations.{{cite news|last1=Fitz-Gerald|first1=Sean|title=Condoms Required for CA Porn Performers: Judge|url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/California-Judge-Issues-Landmark-Ruling-on-Unprotected-Porn-242117921.html|work=NBC Southern California|date=January 27, 2014|language=en}} == See also == * [[Adult Industry Medical Health Care Foundation]] (AIM) * [[AIDS Healthcare Foundation]] * [[Performer Availability Screening Services]] (PASS) ==References== {{reflist|3}} ==Further reading== * {{cite journal |last1=Grudzen |first1=Corita R. |last2=Elliott |first2=Marc N. |last3=Kerndt |first3=Peter R. |last4=Schuster |first4=Mark A. |last5=Brook |first5=Robert H. |last6=Gelberg |first6=Lillian |date=April 2009 |title=Condom Use and High-Risk Sexual Acts in Adult Films: A Comparison of Heterosexual and Homosexual Films |journal=American Journal of Public Health |volume= 99 Suppl 1|issue= S1|pages= S152–6|doi=10.2105/AJPH.2007.127035 |pmc=2724941 |pmid=19218178}} {{Pornography}} [[Category:Condoms]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS]] [[Category:Occupational safety and health]] [[Category:Research on the effects of pornography]] [[Category:STDs in the sex industry]]
